conclusion: A circular wooden board with radius r floats on a liquid surface. A point light source S is located at depth H = √3r directly below the center O of the board. The liquid has refractive index n = √2. We need to find how far upward to move S so light is just not visible above the surface.

When light passes from a medium with higher refractive index to one with lower refractive index (liquid to air), there exists a critical angle beyond which total internal reflection occurs, preventing light from exiting the liquid.
The critical angle C occurs when the angle of refraction equals 90°, using Snell's law: √2 sin(C) = 1 sin(90°)
For the light to be just not visible above the water surface, the rays that graze the edge of the wooden board must arrive at the critical angle.

premise: The distance from the center O to the edge of the board is r, and the depth of S after moving will be (H-x) = √3r - x
